values.title: hand behaves unstably

content.raw:
(I'm not sure whether this is the right repo; feel free to move this ticket.)

Under keyboard teleop (using the GUI plugin), it's pretty easy to make the hand/arm become unstable and explode.  I can do this by rotating the wrist one direction or the other for a while, or by closing a grasp for a long time.  It seems like somebody is not paying attention to joint limits and just ramping up a desired force (probably in a PID somewhere).

values.title: Reset World + Spacenav = jumping behavior

content.raw:
Reset World/Ctrl-r does not reset the position of the Spacenav, causing the arm to jump back to the last commanded Spacenav position after a reset.

Steps to reproduce:

Move the arm using the Spacenav.

Press Edit >> Reset World or Ctrl-r. You should see the arm move back to its original position.

Move the arm with the Spacenav again. It will jump back to the last commanded position.
content.html:

Press Edit >> Reset World or Ctrl-r. You should see the arm move back to its original position.

Move the arm with the Spacenav again. It will jump back to the last commanded position.

values.title: Improper virtual environment perspective in response to head tilt/nod/rotation

content.raw:
The display of the virtual environment in response to motion tracking of the head is not correct for using a static, 3D monitor display.

For example, when mocap is activated, and I tilt my head to the left, the entire environment tilts to the right. While this rendering is correct for a head-mounted display where the display moves with the user, it is incorrect when using a stationary monitor. The environment being displayed from the monitor should NEVER rotate, because the displays rotational axes should be locked in position with the monitor, which never rotates.

This is true for all 3 axis of rotation of the head. The VRE should appear as if it is extending out of the monitor. Moving the head vertically or laterally should change the perspective in the environment, so the 3D environment's perspective changes in response with the user moving in relative to the monitor. I believe the Gazebo environment accounts for this.

In a nutshell, Gazebo displays what should be displayed for a head-mounted display. Corrections need to be made to allow the VRE to properly display the environment from a stationary monitor. The VRE display should have its general frame of reference be the static monitor, not the user's eyes.
content.html:
The display of the virtual environment in response to motion tracking of the head is not correct for using a static, 3D monitor display.

For example, when mocap is activated, and I tilt my head to the left, the entire environment tilts to the right. While this rendering is correct for a head-mounted display where the display moves with the user, it is incorrect when using a stationary monitor. The environment being displayed from the monitor should NEVER rotate, because the displays rotational axes should be locked in position with the monitor, which never rotates.

This is true for all 3 axis of rotation of the head. The VRE should appear as if it is extending out of the monitor. Moving the head vertically or laterally should change the perspective in the environment, so the 3D environment's perspective changes in response with the user moving in relative to the monitor. I believe the Gazebo environment accounts for this.

In a nutshell, Gazebo displays what should be displayed for a head-mounted display. Corrections need to be made to allow the VRE to properly display the environment from a stationary monitor. The VRE display should have its general frame of reference be the static monitor, not the user's eyes.

values.title: Add .world file and ability to change GUI for left virtual hand

content.raw: We may encounter left-handed amputees in research. Currently, the software only has right-handed functionality. A left hand .world file and right/left GUI toggle is needed for this reason. Adjunct to this, the GUI should be adapted for left handed participants. Adaptation of the GUI for left-handedness includes: changing the contact sensor hand model in the GUI to show a left hand; tasks called via the GUI should be able to be oriented for left-handed participants, so the objects are placed on the left side of the table.

values.title: Add ability to toggle GUI visibility

content.raw: Currently, the Gazebo HAPTIX GUI is permanently docked on the left side of the display. There should be an option to show/hide the GUI. This is a major enhancement because research participants cannot be able to see what contact sensors are active in order to eliminate the potentially confounding factor of visual feedback to what sensations we are trying to emulate in their phantom limb.

values.title: Use different motion tracking technology

content.raw: Infrared motion tracking, frankly, is bad for this application. The occlusion of markers is a huge problem for tracking the wrist, especially when the wrist is pronated/supinated. This problem is exacerbated when we must also accommodate for left-handed users (if/when this functionality is added), where it would be 100% necessary to change the marker positions on the head as well as move the camera to the left side of the user to capture the wrist. Magnetic motion tracking, for one, eliminates these problems.
content.html: Infrared motion tracking, frankly, is bad for this application. The occlusion of markers is a huge problem for tracking the wrist, especially when the wrist is pronated/supinated. This problem is exacerbated when we must also accommodate for left-handed users (if/when this functionality is added), where it would be 100% necessary to change the marker positions on the head as well as move the camera to the left side of the user to capture the wrist. Magnetic motion tracking, for one, eliminates these problems.

values.title: MATLAB API hx_connect() command from ethernet-connected computer returns error

content.raw:
I am trying to use the MATLAP API from a computer connected to the Gazebo machine. When I try to connect by executing hx_connect(), an error is returned:

Error using hxgz
The error message identifier is invalid.

Error in hx_connect (line 25)
  hxgz('connect');

I configured the ~/.bashrc file on the Linux machine properly, and I edited the environment variables on the Windows machine running MATLAB R2014b according to the networking tutorial. IGN_PARTITION is named haptix-osrf-02 on both machines. IGN_IP in the ~/.bashrc file matches the inet address found via an ifconfig call to the command prompt. IGN_IP in the environment variable matches the IPv4 address on the Windows machine found via an ipconfig call to the command prompt.

Both machines can ping each other over the command prompts.

values.title: Hand joints at limits cause unexpected coupling.
Stiffen hand PID servo control
Using MATLAB API to control individual model arm motors causes permanent hyperextension of the ring finger

content.html:
Only changing one motor position using the hx_update() command causes the ring finger to hyperextend. Some sample code:

hx_connect();

cmd.ref_pos = [];
cmd.ref_pos_enabled = 1;
cmd.ref_vel_max = [];
cmd.ref_vel_max_enabled = 0;
cmd.gain_pos = [];
cmd.gain_pos_enabled = 0;
cmd.gain_vel = [];
cmd.gain_vel_enabled = 0;

while counter < 2000
    cmd.ref_pos(1) = 0.5 * sin(0.05 * 2.0 * pi * counter * 0.01);
    counter = counter + 1;
    hx_update(cmd);
end
hx_close();

This code was adapted from the included hx_matlab_controller.m file.

After the code I provided above finishes, the API thinks the ring finger is hyperextended as well: 

sens = hx_read_sensors();
sens.motor_pos(11)

ans =

   -0.7982

Note that -0.7982 is outside of the actuator minimum range of -0.7850.

While the target motor, A_wristy (the first indexed motor), works fine, the ring finger hyperextends for the entire time the code is running, and it stays in position after the code finishes. This hyperextension does not occur on any other motor. If I specifically edit the motor_pos hx_update() command structure for the 11th motor, the motor controlling ring finger flex/extension, the problem does not occur. It occurs every time I call hx_update(cmd) where the cmd.ref_pos struct does not specifically define a motor position for A_ring1.

values.title: Problems with MoCap calibration

content.raw:
When loading Motive for MoCap calibration, there are several issues:

* Motive fails to find the OptiTrack Trio on first pass, and therefore cannot run because it cannot locate the license file. The USB cable has to be unplugged and plugged back in to the same exact USB port. Sometimes this doesn't work and the virtual Windows machine needs to be rebooted.
* Motive cannot load any pre-saved project (*.ttp) files without failing to respond. Response failure happens when loading the haptix_osrf.ttp file from the file browser or from trying to open the file within Motive. The only workaround is to make a new haptix_osrf.ttp file from scratch.

On top of the aforementioned software bugs, when Motive does start working, the calibration is not consistent. Calibrations yield inconsistent MoCap even when following the same exact calibration steps. Sometimes HAPTIX will run with good MoCap right away, other times the need for re-calibration is obvious due to the scene being off-monitor or head/hand motions not being properly tracked.
content.html:
When loading Motive for MoCap calibration, there are several issues:

  • Motive fails to find the OptiTrack Trio on first pass, and therefore cannot run because it cannot locate the license file. The USB cable has to be unplugged and plugged back in to the same exact USB port. Sometimes this doesn't work and the virtual Windows machine needs to be rebooted.
  • Motive cannot load any pre-saved project (*.ttp) files without failing to respond. Response failure happens when loading the haptix_osrf.ttp file from the file browser or from trying to open the file within Motive. The only workaround is to make a new haptix_osrf.ttp file from scratch.

On top of the aforementioned software bugs, when Motive does start working, the calibration is not consistent. Calibrations yield inconsistent MoCap even when following the same exact calibration steps. Sometimes HAPTIX will run with good MoCap right away, other times the need for re-calibration is obvious due to the scene being off-monitor or head/hand motions not being properly tracked.

values.title: Add instructions to install libusb when compiling from source

content.raw:
After building `gazebo`, `ing-transport` and `haptix-comm`, I got this error when building `handsim`:

~~~
/home/louise/code/handsim/src/polhemus_driver.c:22:31: fatal error: libusb-1.0/libusb.h: No such file or directory
 #include <libusb-1.0/libusb.h>
~~~

Which I solved by doing

~~~
sudo apt-get install libusb-1.0-0-dev
~~~

This could be added to the README, or maybe if libusb can't be found, polhemus (and hydra?) stuff doesn't get compiled and you just get a warning...?

This could be added to the README, or maybe if libusb can't be found, polhemus (and hydra?) stuff doesn't get compiled and you just get a warning...?

values.title: Support video showing experiment where we use phantom objects

content.raw:
I apologize if this is not the correct place for me to put this, but I couldn't find a better option on the handsim bitbucket page.


For the phantom object function, I have attached a video of one of our experimental sessions using our old virtual prosthetic limb to show you what we are talking about. In this experiment, the volunteer is not looking at the screen (but he does look in other trials), and he is instructed to flex the virtual fingers to a close or far target. Our motor decode interprets his finger location, and stimulation is applied invoking a sensory perception when his fingers are within the targets. When all fingers are in the correct location, the targets go from red to green. An audible beep is heard when all fingers are in the correct location for ~1 second. The volunteer then indicates whether he thinks the targets are close or far. We would like to recreate this experiment in the new VREs.

Note that the targets do not impede the motion of the robot's fingers at all (thus why we want the "phantom" objects). If implementation for the overlap function is not feasible, there is a workaround we can use. This workaround is using an hx_read_sensors() call in an if statement to find when the motors are in a small range of target positions, and a target sphere could be placed roughly in that range of positions. That sphere would have collisions turned off, but would change color when the finger motor is in the range of target positions. This workaround does introduce some error between where the target is located in virtual space and what finger motor positions cause the fingertip to be in the target. This is why it would be nice, but not 100% necessary, to have the ability to precisely determine when the robot's fingers are overlapping with a target.

In this experiment, the volunteer is not looking at the screen (but he does look in other trials), and he is instructed to flex the virtual fingers to a close or far target. Our motor decode interprets his finger location, and stimulation is applied invoking a sensory perception when his fingers are within the targets. When all fingers are in the correct location, the targets go from red to green. An audible beep is heard when all fingers are in the correct location for ~1 second. The volunteer then indicates whether he thinks the targets are close or far. We would like to recreate this experiment in the new VREs.

Note that the targets do not impede the motion of the robot's fingers at all (thus why we want the "phantom" objects). If implementation for the overlap function is not feasible, there is a workaround we can use. This workaround is using an hx_read_sensors() call in an if statement to find when the motors are in a small range of target positions, and a target sphere could be placed roughly in that range of positions. That sphere would have collisions turned off, but would change color when the finger motor is in the range of target positions. values.title: Motor limits unrealistic, motor pos at zero

content.raw:
From email correspondence with Tyler Simpson, UPitt:

"

    deviceInfo = hx_robot_info();

This returns a struct.  When I look at deviceInfo.motor_limit, I expect to see an array of minimum and maximum motor angles in radians, according to the documentation.  The actual values returned seem to be in degrees.  Assuming they're degrees instead of radians, some (but not all) of these limits seem to be off by about a factor of two.  Additionally, the elements corresponding to motors 8,9,10, and 12 appear to be completely incorrect.  I'm getting -3.93e+18 and 3.93e+18 for those motor limits.  

    state = hx_update(cmd);


Calling the update function returns a struct with sensor information.  When I look at state.motor_pos, I expect to see motor angles in radians according to the documentation, but again this appears to be in degrees.  Additionally, the elements corresponding to motors 8,9,10, and 12 are always just zeros, even when those motors are actually moving in the simulation.  

I'm using Matlab 2014b, Client SDK version 0.6.0, and Gazebo Simulator version 0.7.0. "
content.html:
From email correspondence with Tyler Simpson, UPitt:

"

deviceInfo = hx_robot_info();

This returns a struct. When I look at deviceInfo.motor_limit, I expect to see an array of minimum and maximum motor angles in radians, according to the documentation. The actual values returned seem to be in degrees. Assuming they're degrees instead of radians, some (but not all) of these limits seem to be off by about a factor of two. Additionally, the elements corresponding to motors 8,9,10, and 12 appear to be completely incorrect. I'm getting -3.93e+18 and 3.93e+18 for those motor limits. 

state = hx_update(cmd);

Calling the update function returns a struct with sensor information. When I look at state.motor_pos, I expect to see motor angles in radians according to the documentation, but again this appears to be in degrees. Additionally, the elements corresponding to motors 8,9,10, and 12 are always just zeros, even when those motors are actually moving in the simulation.

I'm using Matlab 2014b, Client SDK version 0.6.0, and Gazebo Simulator version 0.7.0. "

values.title: Remove target_link_libraries against gazebo_sensors in TestUtils.cmake

content.raw: Once [Gazebo issue 1568](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1568/gazebo_libraries-out-of-order) is resolved, `cmake/TestUtils.cmake` should link against `GAZEBO_LIBRARIES` only. The `gazebo_sensors` line in `target_link_libraries` should be removed.
content.html: Once Gazebo issue 1568 is resolved, cmake/TestUtils.cmake should link against GAZEBO_LIBRARIES only. The gazebo_sensors line in target_link_libraries should be removed.

values.title: Preferred assignment of bodies 1,2 in HaptixContactPointsCallback

content.raw: The `HaptixContactPointsCallback` gets the contact points that involve a specified model name, with two bodies in contact randomly assigned as link1 or link2. This assignment is important, since the contact information is specified in the reference frame of link1. It would be nice to make sure link1 is part of the specified model.
content.html: The HaptixContactPointsCallback gets the contact points that involve a specified model name, with two bodies in contact randomly assigned as link1 or link2. This assignment is important, since the contact information is specified in the reference frame of link1. It would be nice to make sure link1 is part of the specified model.

values.title: Reset World can mess up keyboard tele-op in local frame

content.raw:
The `HaptixGuiPlugin` uses the rotation component of `armStartPose` when [interpreting keyboard tele-op commands in the local frame](#!/osrf/handsim/src/1778f30a1a5357faab975f6035cf4d73bc88ab27/src/HaptixGUIPlugin.cc#cl-1231). This variable is reset in [OnResetClicked](#!/osrf/handsim/src/1778f30a1a5357faab975f6035cf4d73bc88ab27/src/HaptixGUIPlugin.cc#cl-990) and [OnResetSceneClicked](#!/osrf/handsim/src/1778f30a1a5357faab975f6035cf4d73bc88ab27/src/HaptixGUIPlugin.cc#cl-1003). If a user sets the `Reset World` action, however, then the `armStartPose` will not be reset, since `Reset World` does not trigger resets of GUI plugins (filed as [gazebo issue 1610](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1610/propagate-reset-world-action-to-gui)).

Going in a different direction, can we use the current pose of the arm instead of storing our own copy of it in `armStartPose`?
content.html:
The HaptixGuiPlugin uses the rotation component of armStartPose when interpreting keyboard tele-op commands in the local frame. This variable is reset in OnResetClicked and OnResetSceneClicked. If a user sets the Reset World action, however, then the armStartPose will not be reset, since Reset World does not trigger resets of GUI plugins (filed as gazebo issue 1610).

Going in a different direction, can we use the current pose of the arm instead of storing our own copy of it in armStartPose?

values.title: hx_close() from MATLAB API does not seem to work

content.raw:
Note: using Gazebo v0.8.2

I can execute hx_close() without returning any errors, but I can still update motor positions after execution without calling hx_connect() beforehand. This leads me to believe hx_close() is somehow broken.
content.html:
Note: using Gazebo v0.8.2

I can execute hx_close() without returning any errors, but I can still update motor positions after execution without calling hx_connect() beforehand. This leads me to believe hx_close() is somehow broken.

values.title: Declare minimum gazebo version

content.raw:
Currently `find_package(gazebo)` is [called without a minimum version](#!/osrf/handsim/src/cedb4382f9650e0175428f338ebd7cfacd55932e/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake?at=default#SearchForStuff.cmake-8). We should specify which version of gazebo is required.

Also, there are some deprecation warnings when building against gazebo 6.1, which could be fixed if the minimum Gazebo version is high enough.
content.html:
Currently find_package(gazebo) is called without a minimum version. We should specify which version of gazebo is required.

Also, there are some deprecation warnings when building against gazebo 6.1, which could be fixed if the minimum Gazebo version is high enough.

values.title: Improve SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo test reliability

content.raw:
Some intermittent failures of the `SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo` test were observed. The test was improved in pull request #138, though some superior fixes were proposed in the pull request discussion. That PR was merged as a temporary solution with this issue created to track the better fixes.

## From pull request #138:

While testing other pull requests, I saw some intermittent failures of the `SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo` test:
~~~
[ RUN      ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Wrn] [ImuSensor.cc:91] Deprecation: IMU noise SDF value have changed. Please refer to http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_imu
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:169] ServerFixture load in 1.1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
[Err] [Visual.cc:2165] Unable to insert mesh[Cannot create GL vertex buffer]
world name: [default]
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:152] no polhemus_source model detected using predefine location.
[Dbg] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:159] Polhemus Source Pose [-0.5 0 1.3 3.14159 0 -1.57159]
libusb_open_device_with_vid_pid() failed
Failed to connect to Polhemus
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:323] No usable polhemus setup detected.
Successfully connected to keyboard node
hxs_sim_info() Service call timed out.
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/test/integration/sim_api.cc:167: Failure
Value of: hxOK
  Actual: 0
Expected: hxs_sim_info(&simInfo)
Which is: 1
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:118] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo (2732 ms)
~~~

For the successful tests, I saw the `ServerFixture load` message after the `world name: [default]` message, but the failed tests had this message appearing first. That suggests an initialization problem. The `WorldPlugin`s and `ModelPlugin`s are not initialized until the first `World::Step`, so this PR takes a world step before calling `hxs_sim_info` to ensure that WorldPlugin's and ModelPlugin's have been loaded and makes the `SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo` test more reliable for me.

## Better fix ideas from [discussion of pull request 138](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-requests/138/improve-simapitesthxssiminfo-test/diff#comment-9851647):

just brainstorming a different fix for this kind of simulation startup problem.

*    loop over `hxs_sim_info()` until success (i.e. [HaptixWorldPlugin::Load()](#!/osrf/handsim/src/e7492785a61c78bc76ca0aecbeb03834cea5b962/src/HaptixWorldPlugin.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#HaptixWorldPlugin.cc-125) has finished loading).
*    check to see if `/haptix/gazebo/hxs_sim_info` has been advertised by the simulator before continuing

any suggestions?

thanks,

John

[Dbg] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:159] Polhemus Source Pose [-0.5 0 1.3 3.14159 0 -1.57159]
libusb_open_device_with_vid_pid() failed
Failed to connect to Polhemus
[Wrn] [HaptixControlPlugin.cc:323] No usable polhemus setup detected.
Successfully connected to keyboard node
hxs_sim_info() Service call timed out.
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/test/integration/sim_api.cc:167: Failure
Value of: hxOK
  Actual: 0
Expected: hxs_sim_info(&simInfo)
Which is: 1
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:118] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo (2732 ms)

For the successful tests, I saw the ServerFixture load message after the world name: [default] message, but the failed tests had this message appearing first. That suggests an initialization problem. The WorldPlugins and ModelPlugins are not initialized until the first World::Step, so this PR takes a world step before calling hxs_sim_info to ensure that WorldPlugin's and ModelPlugin's have been loaded and makes the SimApiTest.HxsSimInfo test more reliable for me.

Better fix ideas from discussion of pull request 138:

just brainstorming a different fix for this kind of simulation startup problem.

  • loop over hxs_sim_info() until success (i.e. HaptixWorldPlugin::Load() has finished loading).
  • check to see if /haptix/gazebo/hxs_sim_info has been advertised by the simulator before continuing

any suggestions?

thanks,

John

values.title: Proper GUI when playing back a log
